Staff are very helpful especially Shirley who works in the pet area

Return visitors to this wonderful cottage , The standard and quality of this cottage is outstanding ! Every base has been covered for visitors with mobility and sensory disability's . From wheelchairs to hearing loops and so many more too numerous to list . The amount of Information and guides for disabled visitors is immense . The host's really do go the extra mile to make sure there guests stay is as carefree and happy as possible . I would highly recommend this cottage to anyone ! you will not be disappointed .
You can tell someone has put a bit of thought into making the park accessible.. Impressed at the number of ramps throughout the park. Ramps also built so people can access the digtal displays...

Signage was excellent and there were lifts between the platforms. Had never been to this station before and was able to find my way around easily. Nice clear audio announcements in plenty of time before trains arrived.
Plenty accessible toilet facilities
I did not have need to speak to staff this visit, but generally have found them helpful if I've needed to ask for things

The hotel has excellent disabled access. It had the usual facilities you would expect to find in a Premier Inn hotel restaurant, bar area and there was also a Costa Coffee. The communal areas were step free, with lifts.   I had reserved an accessible room with walk in shower and when I arrived I was allocated what I had requested and I was pleased with the layout and cleanliness of my room.  The hotel although a little bit out of the main city centre has excellent public transport links, which made the location very easy to get to.  The only thing which I felt could be improved upon was the queuing, when I arrived the machine didn't accept my booking, there was a queue at receiption and I had to stand about 5 - 8 minutes before I was served. When I got the receiption I suggested that they have some fold up seats so people with mobility impairments can join, but don't have to stand in the queue. Likewise in the morning queuing for breakfast at the restaurant. These were little things that could make things a lot better for disabled customers, but it wouldn't put me off returning.

During the 1840.s there were three stations in Edinburgh, collectively known as Waverley, but due to congestion at Waverley, plans were put forth to demolish all three stations and build just one large station, and by 1873 the new station was more suitable to take the extra traffic now needed. This soon became apparent it was not able to cope with so much more railway expansions, and a further alteration had to be made, and work began in 1892. It was a Hugh task, now to cover 23 acres  of ground, and it included the new entrance from Waverley Bridge, which had started in the 1873 plans, and a new ridge and furrow system roof was built to lay as low as possible so it would not spoil the city,s skyline. Then the first and second class waiting rooms were built, ( but now, sadly due to the COVID 19 problems, the first class lounge has been closed during 2020/21, and it remains to be seen if it will be reopened. ) Finally, the new station was opened in 1921. Over the years further improvements have had to be made, (bearing in mind the Listed status now held ) so any work has to have Listed building consent. In 1994 the railway was privatised, and by 2004 new projects were put in place, including lengthening of the platforms, and between 2010/2020 the roofs glazing was replaced with 27,000 new panes of glass. (Photo3) It is now one of the largest of all British stations. After having wheelchair assistance to get us off the platform at Waverley station, and along to the concourse (photo 1) which is all on the level, but very busy although we found everyone very friendly and helpful, including a number of passers by, who were very nice in allowing us to move around very easily, and my wife pushed me along to the lift (photo 2). We then rode up and across Waverley stations glass roof,  (Photo 3) exiting we moved along the Bridge walkway, and a long push for my wife, which would take us eventually to the way out for Princess street, to Another lift (photo 4) which took us up to the level needed for Princess street. (Photo 5).  A paved walkway (photo 6) took us along to Princess street (photo 7). All the main bus stops are along here (photo 8) which lead to Edinburgh castle. (Photo 9), and we had quite a view to the castle itself (photo 10). Crossing over Princess street, there are a number of hotels and restaurants. (Photo 11).  Our final thoughts. We enjoyed the train ride to Waverley station, arriving on time, and assistant service was there waiting for us, who took us along past all other platforms, we had arrived at the far end platform, so a long push for wheelchair, but it was easily handled for us, and it was no trouble using a number of lifts to get us up onto Princess street, so overall, an interesting journey, and we would suggest that if you are going to Edinburgh, you consider using the train service, as we found it so convient.

There is one official disabled parking place up at the house. You drive up a private lane/drive to the property. At the top of the drive there is a gate, depending on when you visit, you might have to get out, open it, drive through and get out again to close it.

Excellent, everyone I met was very helpful and friendly and did everything they could to make my experience as smooth as possible. They were happy to lower their masks so I could lipread and provided any important information to me in written form to make sure I could fully understand.
The staff were lovely, and they couldn't do enough to help.
Jane and Stuart were helpful and friendly, offering advice when needed.

Lifts are located on each floor and only a short walk away from the car parking spaces.  Both lifts lead you on to each floor (3) of the gate building. There are also escalators on each floor.  All restaurants and services are easily accessed by wheelchair.

the help point is usually in one spot down the platform.  TFL are trying to upgrade the access but there's only 77 total completed out of 270 odd.  I was informed by a staff member some disability access was removed after completing 2012 olympics, but this is hearsay - although he had no reason to make it up.
There was accessible parking but it was quite a trek from door. I didn't see any bays close by.
Very good accessible on ground floor of the multi storey car park.
Excellent inside the cafe and the shopping centre.   Seats are moveable.

There is a step at the entrance stopping wheelchair users from accessing the shop. However, if you can manage to walk in then you're in for a treat as the ice cream has won many awards and is the best that I have ever tasted. Something needs to be done about the step though, wheelchair users like ice cream too!!
We arrived on a coach which was a bit of a squeeze but we managed it. Decent size carpark with flat or ramped access to all buildings.

There are electrically operated push button doors at the front and rear of the hotel which are normally working but not on this visit. The hotel reception, restaurants and bars are all easily accessible. The accessible bedrooms are huge. These are set up as twin beds with plenty of space around the beds and a further large seating area opposite the beds (excuse poor photo attached). There is also a lot of accessible hanging and storage space for clothes. I have stayed in many hotels and these are by far the largest and most comfortable rooms. See comments on bathrooms

The door to get in is not automatic and quite heavy but staff are always on desk and can help if needed. There is a large reception area with high desk. Past reception on the right is the bar, and restaurant which I had breakfast in. This was a good experience - self serve but things were low down and staff were always around to help if needed. There are lifts past reception that announce floors and doors opening in English. The corridors are spacious enough even if there is a cleaning trolley outside a room. The room itself was brilliant, lots of space and I was very comfortable.
Accessible for wheelchairs.
We only briefly interacted with staff but they were all friendly.
Limitations of heritage site but when otherwise all fine and there was a computer to see the upper castle areas virtually.
friendly
Parking and transport might be an issue for some people as the Ligthouse is set in a side street off Buchanan Street which in itself is pedestrianised.

Poor staff attuide, towards my little boy in a wheel chair , and the family, then when putting a complaints in on a show with the sealions it got brushed off .said this rule apply to everyone. everyone app from the family that sit with the buggys and don't get asked to move like we did .
We visited the disabled toilets so we acknowledged that they were there.
There are signs indicating. No stairs, making it easier. And can't remember entirely but quite sure there are benches along the way.
Very Friendly and helpful
My room had a fully accessible wet room.

Can't comment on the parking. Karlsplatz U Bahn Station (fully accessible) is very close but the lift brings you out in what seemed like the wrong place. The safest route is to exit the station concourse in the direction away from the concert hall then turn left and walk through the gardens. Turn left into an underpass which takes you under the main road and you will find a lift that takes you up about 100 yards from the Musikverein, with no roads to cross.

Several bus routes will drop you off practically outside the restaurant. Highbury and Islington Overground station is nearby, and step-free, but Highbury and Islington tube station is *not* step-free. There is no other step-free station nearby. The nearest step-free tube station is King's Cross, which is well over a mile away.
As expected.

The signs clearly marked the disabled access, and where there were stairs/escalator, there was always an option too for a lift. It is moderately spacious though it might feel crowded to claustrophobic people. There are a lot of places to seat and rest. All the signage was in large print and could easily be read by most people.
All on one level.  Seating provided if necessary.  All prices in large print.
Great.  Fairly new building, so plenty of ramps, lifts and wide doors. Lovely stalls with seats removed, but stools available for carers - we had a great view
Make booking over the phone and table was ready for us they even offered to take our orders at the table instead of the bar and also offered to collect our meals from the  carvery as well
Easy on the flat access. I managed fine with my two sticks to get in and out the doorway.
I think it had just opened but it was I really enjoyed the food and it was cheap!
Friendly, helpful and understanding

The accessible loo is well equipped and is pretty good. It is large enough to manoeuvre and has grab rails. It is just of the main foyer area right next the the ladies loos and is easy to locate. There is enough room for a carer.

The cafe /kiosk is only open and staffed during summer months (early May to end September) . So limited feedback as not possible to quiz staff until later in the year. Park rangers maintain park year round and are helpful.
Didn't use them but if they are in the same league as everywhere else, they'll be good. This is a newly renovated community space.

Whitmuir is a great place to go when you want to escape the busy life of the city of Edinburgh. The drive from Edinburgh was short (under 30 mins). There is disabled parking just beside the main building.At Whitmuir there is a Cafe and bistro (a good selection of cakes, beverages and a lunch menu), Farm Shop (organic food and veg also children's toys), Art gallery(paintings, prints, sculptures and jewellery etc), Plant nursery and Antiques. Most areas are wheelchair accessible with the exception of the plant nursery. The entrance has a double main door and there is a disabled toilet. We have a lovely time. cakes were yummy and it was great to get out into the countryside.
Generally quite an easy and straight forward access - no hassle - for home AND away fans!
Signage good, no steps a well maintained not too steep ramp
The Harry Potter Shop and the photograph experience at platform 9 3/4 was accessible. Situated on and by the concourse you can wheel in and get to see everything.
Considering the age of the building, the access was excellent.
The staff helped with any questions I had and gave me access into the gym to have a look around.

Perfect.  No problems at all for us.   The lift is not massive and the corridors are slightly narrow but saw plenty of adults using wheelchairs getting on fine (though you many struggle with a very power one)
as I recognised building and had been there before I didn't rely on it.
Mixed! Parking a bit of a nightmare - but it was the festival... Lots of bus stops nearby. Plus a tram stop right next door.
Couldn’t not have done more they should be proud of themselves.
all staff helpful
Only used one disabled toilet which was large enough to drive in and out on the scooter
Staff were welcoming and helpful. Everyone spoke English.
Interior access mostly via very steep ramps.  Access to lift restricted to staff only.  Staff not willing to allow access as unaware ramps were steep.
Ramps good but don’t cover all the site.

Once inside, the smooth floors and accessible loo are plus points. However there is a sizeable step at the front door, there's a bit of a trek from the car park, internal steps to the restaurant. The accessible loo needs extra grab rails and an alarm cord in order to be suitable for most needs.
Very helpful and willing, with pleasant attitude towards disabled, and we were made to feel welcomed by them all.
This temporary venue for Edinburgh Rugby  may be good for the players and able-bodied fans but is hopeless for disabled supporters (if I wasn't such a rugby nut, I wouldn't have bothered!)

If you or your child like Space, then this is a nice trip out. Good displays with lots of 'spacey'  information and some interactive play.Completely accessible building with ramps and a lift. The actual building isn't somewhere you can spend a whole day at so I think it is on the expensive side for what it is (small concession discount but no carers in for free).  You can also go on a 60 minute round trip on the ferry.
There are disabled parking spaces available outside the Vikingar centre it is also possible to walk along the prom from the train station .
Local buses, on street parking, down at the bottom of a hill.

Park in private drive, level access to house. If you don't want to drive and there are disabled people in the group, then I don't have any hesitation in recommending C & A taxis in Polis. They have minibuses with lifts in the back and passengers who can't leave their wheelchairs, are anchored to the floor. It costs approx. £140 for a return journey and takes 45 minutes from Paphos airport. When you have to leave your villa, they will collect your luggage and you can either go to C & A when you are ready, and their whole family is very welcoming.
Large car park right next to it, with accessible bays.  We used the postcode for the New Boston Hotel opposite and found it easily.
A first post Covid-19 trip to a supermarket.

no changing place toilet that i saw but spacious toilets with grab rail and one was a closomat toilet.  There was a seat raise but it did not fit on the closomat toilet. There was a second downstairs toilet but it had a sink very close to it so i dont know if the raise seat would have fit on there, my dad would not have been able to get up from that toilet.

Undulation paving, forest type paths or compacted soil. Ramps have lips to get onto them in some areas. Swing doors or heavy doors to the indoor areas and lemur walk though (only open a few hours a day). Penguins have a walkway which does not allow a chair and pram to easily pass. Some enclosures difficult to see. Reptiles are 2-3 'shelves' high. Easy to see big cats, free flying birds, wolves, meerkats, penguins, some reptiles and red pandas from low height.
Great - access to the terminal building easy.
Good, monitored accessible car park.  They divert disabled drivers to additional proximal parking when the lot fills.  There is now an accessible bus that goes around the site.

Staff were exceptionally helpful. With the staff member at the ticket desk taking a good bit of time to explain the best accessible ways to see the different places along the poets path. Also explaining there is large print versions of text which can be requested at reception desk

We visited to see the Wheelchair Tennis Masters 2016 which was sublime.  Inside the building is good for access, though I didn't see a large number of accessible loos (however what there was was good).  There was a free shuttle bus transfer from Stratford on this particular occasion which was fully accessible.  Food venue (on site but separate) was level access though with heavy doors.  Paths outside all level, automatic doors to venue. Tennis Courts had flip up seats and wheelchairs could park up there on front row, anywhere you liked.
Popped in for a coffee, which was good. Pleasant staff served me. Lots of space around counter but not much around the tables unless outside. A ramp enabled me to access more tables and toilet.
Exploring Princes Street and feeling the need to "take time out" it was great to dip into the Gardens and see the green space, grab a coffee and admire the engineering of the Festival Wheel.
Small ramp at entrance, wide doors. Pavement outside quite messy and uneven.
always plenty of staff to help however in busy periods this may not be the case
Did not have the need to use but I did see the door
A wheelchair accessible restaurant. With friendly in store staff.
The staff are very welcoming and kind,caring and nice to everyone.
being able to get round the park on my own

Currently showing the 'School of Rock' musical - which was excellent - the New London Theatre is in Drury Lane, the heart of Theatre Land.  I was surprised by the limited number of spaces for wheelchair users, however those which were there, had a very good view of the stage.

As a support worker this was a working holiday, supporting a lady with special needs who needs a wheelchair whilst out and about. The cottage suited our needs perfectly, spacious for moving around inside cottage. Fabulous wet room, with everything needed to hand. Ideal location for peace and tranquility. Also lovely to sit outside taking in views of beautiful countryside with coffee and cake.

Friendly and helpful both at Amsterdam Centraal Station, on the train and in Paris The stewardess on the train took the trouble to point out the alarm button in the accessible loo, and when no ramp appeared at the Gare du Nord, she phoned through to summon one. The ramp operator was very apologetic about the delay.
The staff were good and helpful.

The grave is about a 15 minutes walk from Great Missenden Train Station. There are regular trains from London. Exiting the station from trains from London, there is a choice of a footbridge with no lift or a step free, slightly uphill path, which is signposted Way Out and with a wheelchair symbol, see photo.   I walked from the station. Then there is a slight hill street down to the High Street. The High Street is flat and walk by the Roald Dahl Museum and turn left into Church Street. I would suggest crossing over to the opposite side of Church Street as it easier to cross here than further up. Then turn right into Church Lane. Soon after the turning the road goes uphill slightly, but enough to make me feel out of breath, see photo. There is one part of the pavement when I visited that was overgrown with brambles and I had to walk on the road. (At this point I got chatting to a lady taking her dog for a walk and mentioned this. She said that unless there is a service/event on at the church there is usually very few cars along that road. A little further up there is a bridge to cross and then directly afterwards the Church of St Peter and Paul is on the right and the cemetery on the left.  If you had a car/ taxi you could go to the entrance of the cemetery.

There are two accessible toilets. One in the main diner and one accessed from the ramp for outside diners. I've never used the outside one but the inside one is lovely and clean, big enough to turn around in and easily accessible.

I was very impressed at the number of lifeguards there were at all areas of the Park and how attentive they were. In several places there are lifeguards actually standing in the water, not just looking on from a distance.  The park is extremely clean, considering how many people visit it, there is no rubbish or anything left lying about. There are staff cleaning constantly.  All staff I spoke to were helpful.

Over the years I have visited La Cala De Mijas many times, which is in the Costa Del Sol, Spain.  In the past it has not been the most accessible place, however, the community and local committee have been working to change that. They have taken up all of the public paths and replaced them, making them wider and ensuring they are all level and accessible for wheelchairs, which makes getting around the town a lot easier. Furthermore, they have put boardwalks all along the beach so people who may have mobility difficulties are able to access the beach and sea, with regular monitoring from lifeguards. At the Lifeguard station they have made accessible sun-loungers on a level access floor on the beach and have also provided wheelchairs and walking sticks that can be used on the sand and in the sea to make access into the water easier for everyone. they have also included a disabled friendly outside shower on the beach, and this is based near a disabled toilet. The Lifeguards are always willing to help and are very friendly and regularly patrol the whole of the beach. All of the public transport is very cheap and accessible for wheelchair users.  This is a great holiday destination for families to visit as they are constantly looking at new ways to improve their facilities.

This is where the 'bad' bit comes in. From the ground floor access is made to the loo upstairs via a lift. It tends to be mucky inside and out. The accessible female toilet is at the dear end of the ladies toilet - that's not a problem, personally, but despite the sink inside and soap (if it's a good day!) there is no hand-drying facility available.
Couldn't get in because of a small step, so unfortunately can't comment.
All very friendly, kind and helpful.
Due to the layout/design of the building, toilets are situated pool-side (though bear in mind this is an Edwardian building). There is a disabled access toilet and changing facilities.

Majority of airport has good access. As mentioned drop off points for access quite a distance from airport entrance. Airport assistance is available and help phones situated throughout airport, it's advisable to pre book assistance with airline beforehand. Once security has been cleared, extremely steep ramp needs to be accessed, impossible for self propelling manual wheelchair, and challenging for those assisting! Problems accessing plane as the ambulift was not placed flush with door of plane, despite saying that was as close as they could get it, they managed to get it flush after the air stewardess suggested they got a lift on chair( I'm on the large side) same problem on the way back with ambulift. These were the least helpful of all the staff in the airport. Allowed to take my crutches onto plane, and given a seat near the front. I have travelled all over the world , and this is the only airport where there has been problems ,getting the ambulift close to the door.
The accessible loo was available and had a reasonable size room and facilities. It was clean and very usable
There isn't any parking as its in the center but car parks close by.
Just over 3 miles from Droitwich, the Aztec adventure park was quite easy to find using sat NAV.

All the staff and volunteers were very helpful all going out of their way to make sure that they guests had a very good respite experience.  As I have been several times I received a very warm greeting.  It would be wrong to single out anyone who was “particularly helpful” because they all were.

This was my first visit to the Dakota hotel in Glasgow. I had visited their hotel at euro central, it's just off the M8 motorway on the way to Motherwell, so I knew what standard to expect and I wasn't disappointed. Their buildings look like something from Gotham city in a Batman movie. Inside the hotel the lighting is quite low so may cause problems for people with visual impairments, I think this is to create a Gothic feel to the place.
Good size and clean. Liked the sign beside the door!
Staff did very well to help get a specific room that would accommodate my needs and were available for any more assistance

Access in and around the building:  The main entrance has a traditional revolving door. Alongside is a small ramp built into the entrance and a wide access door. It was easy to get through and a concierge was quickly on hand to hold the door.  Once in the building the reception is in front of you. There were plenty of staff on hand.  The building is on several floors. One of many lifts leads from reception to the upper floors. My powerchair is quite large at 68 cm wide and 116 cm in length so I used the service lift – not that I knew it was a service lift until later.  The wide corridors to the accessible bedrooms were amazing. Once had enough space for a seating area and a piano! Apparently this stems for from the days of ladies in the grand ball gowns not wishing to touch another lady’s gown as they swept along the corridor to the grand staircase.  Access in the accessible bedrooms and bathrooms:  The accessible bedroom was a surprise in that the door opened to reveal so much space. The room door had a clearance of 86 cm so plenty of room to wheel in.  There were no tight corners and tricky turns to be done here! With access to both sides of the beds and a large seating area it was great.  The accessible wet room was spacious and had a door the same size as the room door; again no tight turns. With an integral shower and plenty of space around the toilet it worked well for me.  The two accessible rooms are identical.   Access in the dining area:  The hotel offers several items for dining or getting light refreshments. Peacock Alley offers a lounge style area where you can relax and admire the old station architecture or just watch the gentle movement of the station clock as time ticks away.  The adjacent Brassiere provides breakfast and other dining options during the day. The hotel’s Pompadour restaurant offers fine dining and great views. I visited all three during my visit and they were all easy to get in and move around. Furniture could be moved to make access easier and the staff were magnificent.  Access to other facilities:  The hotel does have a spa and swimming pool. I ventured down to visit these and whilst not going as far as swimming I can confirm that there is an accessible changing room!
A completely unexpected access experience. A tunnel built in 1902 so that south London residents could go to work in the docks on the Isle of Dogs turns out to be a great find.
You go through a door and go past the disabled toilet and your seat is right there.
You can park on the high street next to the coffee shop
The bus goes from the high street nearby. I think you can park on streets nearby.

Can't fault it, just take care in the car park as lighting is poor and seeing little pot holes was a little difficult.   No steps, not even any lips or door ways steps to manoeuvre. Was dark inside but it was an awards ceremony so always going to be a little dimmer.
It's all flat.
Just asked for a table suitable for wheelchair, given a choice of places, chairs removed without trouble to give access.
I found the wheelchair access to be good apart from the difficulty with the paths, which were uneven and steep in many places.
Brilliant. Live the lift.
Excellent, the event centre has recently installed a changing place facility making days out more accessible for all.  Without this it is difficult to enjoy family days out.

Poor old lovely Thekla, it is a boat, on three levels, so not the easiest venue for the mobility impaired.   There are rather a lot of stairs.  See disabled access details below.  They do give free carer passes though, if you call them in advance.  The staff are generally friendly and helpful.

The journey here was okay. We came, as advised by the site, from Skipton up a B road to Grassington, which was fine. You turn left off this road in Thresfields, up a long dead end. Initially, this is a normal road but the last km or so is the narrowest single track road ever! I was driving the car and had to do a double take. Hubby was following in the motorhome. He must have wondered where we were going. Glad we took the car, as days out, getting the motorhome up and down that lane would have been stressful!
Apart from the odd incline, the interior was all level access.  Corriders were a bit narrow and turns rather tight for wheelchairs; rooms however were a good size.
The restaurant car park is directly next to the ramped, level access.  Good bus service
There is great disabled access to the commonwealth pool. I find it very easy to find my way around. However, I think it might be quite difficult to use if you are a wheelchair user.

The staff a very helpful,polite, they can't do enough to help you. They are really fantastic with the children, they helped with Adams equipment. Near steps , the food is really good would recommend the waterfall cafe.

We stayed here overnight in one of the hotels accessible rooms. I cannot recomend it highly enough. The room was very spacious with 2 twin beds. The room had an on suite bathroom with handrails and a pull down shower seat. There is a red cord in the shower. Ther is also an emergency call button in the room itself. Staff are so friendly and helpful and complete an personal Emergency Evacuation plan with all Disabled guests. All Travelodge accessible rooms should have wet room bathrooms available.
No wheelchair access apart from slope from car park leading to step into building.
quite difficult to find but there were a couple toilets
There is a large step up into the pub and the pub doesn't have a wheelchair ramp and the staff don't care.

Run by a highly-talented husband and wife team, this cafe serves savoury meals as well as patisserie and great coffee. It is also a good place to buy bread. The only reason we haven't given this venue five stars is that there is no accessible loo. It is excellent in every other way.
Designated parking outside each of the properties . We stayed at Hidelow house which sleeps 4 .
It has step free access to the premises. It's quite tight with tables inside but the staff got me a suitable table.
Path along side edge of car park goes to toilet.    Terrain rough underfoot for a manual or powerchair but you can buy an ice cream and stay at the top and enjoy the views.
Small public gardens, next to the entrance to the Old Fortress. Originally known as Bosketto Gardens, but was re-named Bosketto Durrell in 2016, in honour of the writers Gerald and Lawrence Durrell.
The staff were nice and good service, although I didn't need any extra help.

Friendly staff who ask if you need assistance and will come to the table to serve you from a bar menu. Easy assess from car park outside. Clean, well arranged disabled toilet. Has a disabled room on ground floor with parking right outside for an overnight stay.
Croy railway station is easy to access with ramps to both platforms, an accessible toilet, good parking, bus links, and very helpful staff.

There were 3 steps with a handrail into the main entrance. Once inside everything was step free and on the ground floor. La Rotonde restaurant is on the ground floor. There is step free access to the main restaurant but the mezzanine level is only accessible by stairs. I ate my dinner in the restaurant's garden, which had step free access, and a view overlooking the Prom des Anglais. There were free standing tables and chairs.
Not sure about public transport access but no problem parking in the dedicated parking space outside the chalet.

For me, access to public transport was important as a visually impaired person.  Frequent buses pass by the front door to all parts of the city. There are bus stops on both sides of the road and traffic lights make for a safe road crossing.

I managed to get into the disabled toilet but it was a bit tricky. There was not a lot of room to turn round in front of the door to go in straight. And inside the toilet, the space was only just big enough for my powerchair.  It could have been better but it could also have been worse.
Roomy toilets

I was meeting a group of friends for lunch at the cafe of the Forth Valley Sensory Centre. It had been a number of years since I had visited the sensory centre and I had only been there for work meetings previously so was nice to visit in a more social capacity. I notified the venue that I would be arriving to meet friends for lunch using the Welcome by Neatebox app they have installed which alerts staff to any accessibility and assistance requirements you have before you arrive at their venue. I arrived with a fellow guide dog owner and we were met at the entrance of the building and shown through to the cafe where some of our friends had already arrived.
Getting in is OK but they have baskets around that make it awkward, items are out of reach and there is a lack of staff to help
They have accessible toilets, which are accessible on the 2nd floor next to the cafe.

North Berwick High Street can be a bit of a nightmare to park in. We were very lucky and parked right outside hence the 5 star rating. If you are unlucky you might find you have to park a long way away.

Easy to find as the lift up to the 3rd floor opens at the cafe. Easy to order food and drinks. Space to park my scooter alongside a table. Not expensive. Disabled toilet was quite small as my photo shows and the red cord wasn't long enough.
The venue is well away from adequate parking and public transport. The venture itself has some obvious positives but some very big negatives.

Nearest tube station is Piccadilly Circus but this is not wheelchair accessible. There are plenty of buses on Piccadilly.  Nearest carpark is in Leicester Square. We parked for free in the Royal Academy opposite as we were visiting an exhibition - there are 2 BlueBadge parking spaces which you can book in advance.
Friendly attentive staff
Access was easy to parts of the public site and the have a changing place toilet
Visited for a quick drink on New Years Eve and was pleasantly surprised at the facilities in such a small space!

Step free access to get in, it was easy to get around inside- plenty of space. It was quite well signposted and we enjoyed having a nosey about. I could reach most of the shelves which was nice! In the cafe the tables are quite low and in my power chair I cant get underneath, I imagine manual chairs with armrests also wouldn't get under although your legs might! The chairs are hard wood so I didn't transfer into one. It is table service and the staff were friendly and helpful. We enjoyed out coffees and cakes, at 4 o clock the staff were cleaning and putting chairs on tables and at 4:30 they started sweeping and mopping which kind of ruined the vibe so we left early, the cafe shuts at 5.
There are disabled parking spaces right next to The Sandcastle.

There are two accessible toilets and the CP toilets. I followed the signs that were clearly marked and directed me to the toilets on the first floor where the management suite can be found. I did not take much notice of the two accessible toilets however as the CP toilets were at a very high standard I would expect that they would be as well. In the Changing Places toilet there was: Bench - Height Adjustable, Adult Sized, Wall Mounted Hoist - Ceiling Toilet Washbasin Height Adjustable Emergency Alarms Privacy Screen
Access to the swimming pool is very easy for all with disabled access and facilities.

No steps, completely flat except for a very small ramp to go to the gym and one of the smaller sports halls. Apart from that you can access every room.  It must be good if you've got so many disability sports clubs running down there :)
Easy access to viewing platform, great view of stage. However ramp was steep
The staff were fantastic and could not have done any more.

Access across the railway at Westerton Train Station used to be via a narrow pedestrian bridge making it very difficult for anyone with impaired mobility to access both platforms.  The old bridge was replaced in 2018 by a new wider bridge and lifts have been installed making it easier for all passengers to cross the railway to the opposite platform.
All staff are friendly and very helpful. Restaurant staff reserved a table for us beside the buffet
To busy to be helpful, reception staff not at all interested, and waitress staff also quiet busy on our visit, so it’s disappointing.

There is a ramp to the front door. The ramp is of a solid stone construction and is rather steep. Not horribly or impossibly steep, but a bit of an effort in a manual wheelchair and it could be a bit of a skid if you come down it in the rain.   The front door is a bit heavy but there are always people who jump out of nowhere to help.   The café is small and it can be quite difficult and awkward to find a comfortable place to park in your wheelchair for a nice relaxed snack or drink, because the tables and seating are quite crammed together.
too many cars on forecourt, not a single disabled space, sloping surfaces make wheelchair use extremely difficult

If arriving by public transportation, Groet is accessible by bus from the Alkmaar train station. If you have special needs, be sure to call in advance to ensure the bus is suitable for your needs.  If arriving by taxi, the company Accessible Travel Netherlands can make arrangements for you.  If traveling by car, accessible parking is available near the restaurant.  The restaurant can also be accessed from many of the bicycle trails in the area.

Good space and grab rails round the loo. Not sure whether side transfer is feasible - we couldn't work out whether/how the baby changing bench (which is close to the loo) folds up. The washbasin is approachable and there's the usual Ditch round the room at skirting board level alarm cord.

Just had a quick peek in the loo, not enough room to take my scooter in, whilst it appears larger than a normal sized loo there wasn't a lot of room for manoeuvering a wheelchair and having an assistant. It was clean and easy to locate, with a grab rail.

There are disabled spaces surrounding George Square but these are for permit holders at the University of Edinburgh. There is a risk of a ticket if you do not have a permit as well as a blue badge. There are many bus routes around the area, 7, 14, 35, 300, 31, 23. These have lowered buses and ramps for wheelchair users. For those who self propel or have difficulties walking it is a fair distance from most bus stops to the venue over uneven ground and cobbles. The nearest train station is Waverley.

The crew on board the ship consisted of the captain and permanent crew who taught and showed us the volunteer crew what to do. The crew were very good at teaching us the ropes and safety while we were at sea.

We went to the cafe first which is on the ground floor. There are automatic doors and then level access. Next to the cafe are male/female/accessible toilets.  There is a lift to go to the main arena - we didnt realise at first that the lift is outside, beside the stairs. So if in the cafe, you need to go back out to this. It is signposted on the wall outside, but high up, and we hadn't noticed it, however staff were helpful when we asked about it.  From the lift, you go to level 3, and it is then level access. In the foyer (when basketball on) there are a variety of food and merchandise stands. There are also can/snack machines throughout.  In the arena there are many wheelchair spaces all on the same level as the entrance and foyer. They each have at least one seat next to them and are in short rows spaced right around the arena.  Steps to other seats. Yellow edging on steps but didn't have handrails most of the way. Flip-up seats.  For Basketball the arena was quite noisy. This might not suit everybody, but for others it adds to the experience and atmosphere.
Very helpful and nice.
I didn't use it but there was one so I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt!
Parked in the car park next to bowls club on Commercial road. Had plenty of disabled bays. Got 1 extra hour parking. Was fairly easy to get to the cafe - no major hills.

From the moment I arrived at the venue, I was guided by friendly staff every step of the way. The music room is via a short lift journey. A member of staff them made the crowd part so that I could be escorted to my wheelchair spot like a VIP.  Located at the front, I was immersed in the show from start to finish!

We arrived in Cardiff by train, there is a train station next to the hotel although you need to walk around the block (250 yds approx) to the disabled access entrance. There was on street parking outside the hotel although we didn't use it. As the hotel is in the city centre, accessible public transport is good. There is also a dedicated mobility assistance vehicle which you can book or flag down.
Staff were helpful and when asked where things were gave clear and accurate directions.
Lots of disabled parking. I don't think you could get there via public transport -even if you can use public transport

The only let down here is there is no emergency cord apart from that the toilet is accessible very easily for a disabled person on their own  although door may be a problem for the person to close on their own as opens outwards.

W H Smith is generally accessible throughout, with level entrance. Front doors are automatic, and 1400mm wide. Till height is 1000mm, with a side writing ‘desk’ at  820mm. Induction hearing loop available at the till. No Braille aids but they have a magnifying glass. No seating available. Staff are friendly and will shop for customers who find it difficult to move around.

The toilet in the room was large and had the standard grip rails around the toilets and shower you expect in a hotel  There is a fold down seat in the shower that is set at a standard level they  normal are  when you switch the bedroom lights off at night a Green safety light comes on in the toilet that allows you to see with out putting lights on during the night  The only problem was the Red cord was around 2 feet short of the floor I did leave a Red Cord Card in place
Step free access, space to move around within the space, and staff willing to help.
Plenty spaces, but a bit cramped.

Flat easy access into bui!ding. Easy to manoeuvre with chair or scooter and a choice of places to eat and drink. Nice views. Biggest improvement is massive toilet, accessed using RADAR key. It has full size file down bed. Tracks are fitted to ceiling for hours use. The sink moves electrically up and down. It's not perfect but one of the best I've seen. Lots of room to move around but why to do many put the soap / towels in such an inaccessible place.

When arriving at Morrison's I could see there was ample blue badge spaces situated near the front of the store.  The store entrance is covered over and is on the same level as the car park making access easy.  Once inside the store I could see the isles were wide enough for their own shop mobility scooters, and suitable for most wheelchairs or walking aids.  The toilets are easily accessible and just inside the entrance to the right, next to the kiosk. The toilets are locked, and you can obtain the key from staff at the kiosk.  Staff were very bright, friendly and accommodating, advising location of wheelchair trolleys.

Family of 8 plus 2 dogs.  Kraig has cerebal palsy, epilepsy, and hydrocephalus, he is non-weight bearing and confined to a wheelchair.  He is unable to use controls so is fully dependant on his family.  We needed an accessible property that was suitable for quite a large family and accommodated pets too.  We also wanted the use of a swimming pool with hoist access for Kraig.  Heath View met our requirements and more.  The owners have thought of everything, there is so much to do you do not need to leave the area.  There was indoor table tennis and table football.  Chickens and ducks in the shared gardens, along with trampoline, huge sandpit, in-door heated swimming pool and also a hot tub.  There are plenty of books, games, and toys to keep the little ones amused.  A well equipped kitchen, and utility area.  The area feels tranquil, peaceful and rural, yet only a short drive away is numerous restaurants, cinema and shops.  The pictures do not do this place justice.
handy for city centre, car parking for guests available locally.
Green Park tube station is about half a mile away and is fully step-free, served by Victoria, Jubilee and Piccadilly Lines.

It is six years since Lauriston Farm changed from Brewers Fayre to Toby Carvery, but I must confess that this is the first time I have been there since - I was pleasently surprised.  Good food, good service and decent access.
Toilets were acceptable - which is better than most public facilities. They were modern

A lovely countryside driving area, takes you to this farm, with a very large car park, laid with compressed chippings and easy to push around.  There are just two disabled bays, but all bays are easy enough to use.

Virtually the whole garden is accessible. The paths are mainly tarmac or fine gravel, some are rougher gravel and some are grass – this was a bit bumpy for comfort but we didn’t have to go that way, we could have back tracked and stayed on the smoother paths. There are also plenty of benches.

No signage, but resort map  provided. Flat access everywhere on the site. Lifts to the room, smooth limestone floors everywhere. Wheelchair accessible rooms in hotel.with plenty of room, beds with legs for hoist access, shower seat, grab rails and raised loo in bathroom. No access to room's balcony. Access not guaranteed in apartments. Ramps and absence of steps meant the whole site was accessible except for the beach terrace and Dead Sea access. The spa offered flotation in Dead Sea waters as an alternative. The spa was partially accessible and pools on the site had ladder and step access but no pool hoist available. Dining room  had part accessibility, with other restaurants and bar all with full access. Staff were incredibly helpful.
There is a carpark with disabled bays close to the entrance. I've been to this attraction many times and never had a problem finding a disabled bay.

The disabled car parking spaces were extremely wide, so the car doors were able to open to their full potential to ensure that a disabled or wheelchair user can easily get in and out of the car. There is no restricted access to the rear of the vehicle either, so that a ramp can easily be located for assistance. The spaces are located near to the entrance, with the pathway there being level.

This is an art gallery in Saskatoon, in Saskatchewan, Canada. It houses some interesting pieces of art, with a big focus on the history of the area. The buildling itself is beautiful. The name of the museum/gallery is written in one of the local native languages, with the name in all the other languages displayed above a cute fireplace in the lobby.  There is a gorgeous shop and restaurant (though do watch for the tendency to make you wait standing up while they faff around). They host visiting exhibitions too so there is always something interesting to see.

I took my mobility car and found no parking near the store. Also some of the car parks are small with only two or three disabled spaces meaning I had to park further away. This is not great when the weather is bad.

Wheelchair access is excellent throughout. Avoid the cobbled front courtyard by taking the pavements running around its perimeter. Stone ramps lead to the main entrance. Staff are quick to spot you and will open the flat (non-revolving) doors. The lift to upper floors is brilliant and spacious. Full marks.
No automatic door, section we were in was a bit cramped.
The staff were all very nice and friendly and offered additional help if needed
There is no disabled parking but there are spaces near by. Bus stop right outside
Accessible parking is available
Staff very polite, friendly and helpful.
There are no step-free stations nearby but several bus routes serve the area. I wouldn't dream of trying to park anywhere nearby.

Parking was on public streets in Chester, directly outside. The streets are semi pedestrianised with some cobbles but plenty of drop downs. Chester Bus Station is in the next street for public transport links.
Can’t fault them in anyway, great attitude, welcoming, friendly and informative - really give the impression they like being there and care.
The staff are very friendly and will accommodate those who require assistance.

The journey along the river is very pretty and there is enough to spend two half days ( or one full day) enjoying the attractions at either end (rare breeds farm one end and otters and butterflies and station facilities at the other). There is also a miniature outdoor railway and river walks if you don't mind some grassy path sections. Train is very easy to access at Buckfastleigh which has the better station facilities.

This Review has been left via Sculthorpe Moors Trip Adviser.    I'm so pleased that I stumbled across this Little Gem whilst looking online for reserves with wheelchair access!  When we arrived at the visitor centre the staff couldn't have been more helpful. I had my crutches with me as I can't walk very far at all without sitting down, but the staff lent me a wheelchair and let us park further down where the boardwalk starts.   The very first birds we saw included 3 beautiful male Bullfinches and 1 female, Blue, Great and Marsh tits, Greenfinches, Chaffinches, Goldfinches, Goldcrests and Nuthatches.  The reserve is an enchanting mix of woodland, marshland, rivers, dykes and reeds. It truly is a beautiful place and I can't wait to go back as soon as possible.  There are several hides, all wheelchair accessible with large windows low enough so that people  can get a good view. There is a Hide 4 meters above the ground. Even this is wheelchair accessible via a long ramp.
All of the staff were excellent, they are all professional and very aware of disability needs as far as clay shooting goes.

The doors to the entrance are not automatic so require manually opening unless they have been wedged at the door. The whole of the restaurant is level access except one part of the seating area has steps up to the seats. There are however plenty of level access seats elsewhere in the restaurant. The tables are close together so may need moving and arranging to fit a wheelchair in.
Easy to find with space to manouvre/include a carer, but not super clean.
The signage was great from my point of view however i did not notice any braille.
Apparently they do have a disabled toilet, but it cannot be accessed by wheelchair as it is on a different level
Busy and popular pizzaria in a lively, padestrianised street.
Very good happy to bring our drinks up to the top level (top bar is not open in the daytime)

There is ample parking with blue badge designated parking spaces near both entrances. There is a bus stop just outside the centre which is covered by quite a few different bus routes. There is also a taxi rank just outside.

Car park shared with other buildings but disabled parking is closest to the Science Centre building.  A considerable walk from car park to entrance if you are using sticks. We did not know but we're told by staff that our parking ticket was put through a machine which cancels out the fee. Therefore disabled parking is FREE.

There is a loo in the swimming pool changing area, which felt a little cramped, but had everything I needed. There is another accessible loo too, which felt less cramped though, as it didn’t have any other equipment in it.

During my visit i was assessing how accessible asda in newmains was for disabled access, overall i would conclude that my trip was very good. In the car park there is a number of disabled car parking spaces right next to the shop entrance making it very easy to enter the store. The store is all on one level making this extra accessible for people in wheelchairs or with walking aids etc. There are a few disabled toilets which are also all easily accessed on the ground floor.

The G & V Hotel is a modern building with a prime location on the George IV bridge and adjacent to the Royal Mile. With seven accessible bedrooms; four with interconnecting rooms it’s a great location being only a short distance from many of Edinburgh’s tourist attractions.
Enough space and had rails.

South side Scran  The Southside Scran (see photo) opened in a December 2018. We went at the end of January. The bistro is wheelchair accessible. Inside the dining areas are on split levels. We sat at a table that was at pavement level. It was tucked around the corner and so away from any drafts from the entrance door. We were lucky as there were only a few other customers in that particular area and so it was relatively easy to move the wheelchair around. If there had been people on the  surrounding tables it might have been a little tight for space.  The lower dining area is approximately 4 steps down. I am not sure if they have a ramp which would allow access to wheelchair users. I would suggest that when booking it would probably be best to ask for a table that is at pavement level. The food was delicious (see photos) and the staff were lovely and helpful. There is a disabled toilet near the entrance. We drove to the bistro and parked just outside after the bus stop.we went on a Thursday evening but it may be more difficult at different times of the day and different days of the  week. There are also  several buses which stop near to the venue. I would definitely recommend the Southside Scran. We all had a great evening.😋

Access via ramped entrance at side of building. Not used by able bodied so no trampling over you at the end of a show. On arrival you ring the bell on door and a member of staff will let you in and escort you to the bar or auditorium. There is a lift to first floor where bar is. Staff are happy to help and disabled aware. I like how the staff speak directly to my wheelchair bound husband and not me, making him feel valued. Visibility of stage from where the wheelchair spaces are is very good.
Wheelchair accessible community cafe offering excellent homebakes and light meals.
I would advise on taking a taxi to and from Maspalomas but the kerbs are difficult for wheelchair users.
Fine if you can use sticks but a big step for those who cannot transfer.
Parking available on Albert Place and surrounding streets - if you're lucky. Plenty of buses on Leith Walk (city-bound stop right outside) and a taxi can drop off outside.

There are clearly signed accessible toilets. They are of a good size for manoeuvring a wheelchair and we have always found them to be clean. The ground floor accessible loo is in a rather busy spot just inside the main foyer and you need to be careful when opening the door not to bump into someone. It is also a busy spot to wait if the loo is in use.
Possible

Lovely restaurant that has just been extended. Fully wheelchair accessible, all on one level. A fantastic store with high quality home decor, homeware, gifts, food, and plants. Wheelchairs to borrow at the entrance.

Disappointing. There is a step to get up to enter the hotel, and no ramp could be seen. It is quite hard for wheelchair to get past reception desk and into the lift, which is rather small and tight, and I took off rather a lot of skin on my Knuckles as I tried to get in lift. It was untidy in its hall as well, and as it next to reception desk, we had to wait a few times for staff to finish helping other guests before we could get to the lift, which by the way, we didn’t mind. However, we did see all we needed to, most of the building is on the level, and there are plenty of seating areas.

I arrived by train with Virgin Express which was fantastic. However the communication and release of tickets with shuttle bus details at the festival end was very confusing and last minute. This late release of details extended to those using the park and ride as the festival were deciding whether it would be safe to let people park on a floodplain...From other people's experiences, I heard that this decision-making delay also led to a late release of accessibility information which accompanied tickets.

The staff made this stay what it was.  From check-in as explained above to the bar staff taking my drink to table.   The best of the staff were the ladies that worked the breakfast shifts who got my breakfast with me (it was self service) and brought it to my table.   One even came up and gave me  a chocolate muffin for later.    Edit:  I just wanted to add that I complained to Hilton about the parking charge, via an email address I got from their twitter, and they are sending me a cheque to refund the parking charge.
Fully adapted wetroom and toilet, plus a separate toilet with grab rails, handles etc. Loads of room and very well thought out.

Over all the access is very good from both entrances to the building which is only a few years old. If you enter via the front of the building the lifts are on the left hand side past the reception desk .  The lifts are modern and while you will get a wheelchair in to them you might struggle with a mobility scoter unless it is the small fold up type.
The access for this venue is good in that it is all on one level and there are no steps. The spaces are generally open with good room to manoeuvre. There didn’t appear to be any steps.

The staff were very helpful when my husband went in to book a table, making sure that the one they allocated would be suitable. The waitress was especially careful checking food would suit my allergies.

Getting into the Resource Centre was through an automated door where you press a button to gain access. Once inside there's a lowered reception counter which was good. No resting your chin on the counter here!   The corridors were wide and clearly defined and easy to negotiate using my powerchair. All areas I visited were accessible and where there were doors these were easy to manage.
On street parking available and free for blue badge holders. Plenty of spaces in front of the cafe and in the surounding area.

When travelling by car, the car park has many spaces with a couple of disabled parking spaces close to the entrance. The car park is all flat making it very easy to access the entrance. The bus stop is close by the pub, however the venue is located on a busy main access road into York and therefore crossing to return back into York can be challenging and would require someone to have good road safety.
There were two spacious accessible and clean toilets.
This Leisure Centre has an accessible swimming pool, accessible gym and accessible games hall.

The coffee shop is accessed via the New Look clothing store and a lift. Access is pretty good although anybody unable to press the lift button may have to wait a bit for assistance, however there always seems to be somebody around. There is lots of space in the lift and the coffee shop itself. I could easily turn in my powerchair between tables and in front of the counter. The decor is nice and the acoustics are really good for a coffee shop making it easy for me to chat with my P.A. All of this created a calm and inviting atmosphere. The only downside for me was the toilet and the staff, who were friendly enough but did not offer any assistance. This may have been due to their lack of experience.
Staff very friendly and helpful,nothing seemed to be be too much trouble to them.

On arrival we asked at cash desk if it was accessible, we was told yes but they were unsure if tractor ride was. First problem we had was gravel uneven path, Dylan who is strong manual chair user needed help from me. Next stop was food at kernel kitchen situated outside. Couldn't access the order area as step up. We left Dylan at bottom and ordered food. The seating was all picnic benches which we couldn't get wheelchair under. We then tackled some mazes, all accessible. Then to major disappointment Dylan couldn't access any of all the other lovely stuff. Remote control boats, mural painting, maze of confusion, tractor ride etc as they all needed accessing via wooden stepped platform. None had ramps. Due Dylan being very upset we ended up leaving after 1hr 45 mins there and spending £39.50 to get in. That cost was for 1adult & 2 kids.
Staff were fantastic, encouraging, friendly and all seemed to have and a good understanding of ASN. 5*

Went for a hot chocolate around 11:30am when it wasn’t too busy. For someone in a wheelchair the doors are push or pull making it difficult for them to open it on their own. There is a disabled toilet but there isn’t a very clear path for them to get to it due to tables and chairs blocking the path. Although the coffee shop is all one level and has accessible tables inside and out and has disabled parking at the door.

I was impressed by the access and the helpfulness of the staff when I raised a couple of small issues that would make the experience even better for wheelchair users. The entrance doors were automated and and I had the option to use one of two available platform lifts to get up to the main public level of the building. Getting around the exhibition space was easy and I could see and enjoy the displays. The cafe area was easily accessible, as was the shop, the information desk, and the Reader Registration desk.

Superb service from the staff. As we would have difficulty going up to order and managing the self service drinks machine staff quickly provided table service. Checking during the course of the meal to make sure we were OK. Couldn't have been more attentive!
The accessible toilet near the reception was well signposted, fairly spacious and more than adequate.
Good smooth surfaces and wide paths but very uphill.
We arrived by car. We found the cottage easily using google maps and there was parking right outside the front door for 2-3 vehicles.

We drove to the area because we were going to look in a few different shops around Mono. We managed to get on street parking behind the strip of shops, but it was quite busy. There are good transport links though, as it is in the city centre.
Access to the Premier was generally good. If you are visiting the ExCel Centre it's a great spot being only a short walk from Prince Regent DLR and the Centre.

Lots of staff and very well in tune with people who were disabled or requiring assistance, the bus to Glasgow had a drop level floor and a lady staff member provided a customer in her wheelchair with attendance and accessing the bus, this was reciprocated at Buchanan Street in Glasgow.

level access , automatic doors , wide foyer , no doors into the public areas , including the restaurant. Ample lifts with good space inside so no problems for wheel chairs getting to all floors. The accessible bedroom I stayed in had a working automatic door which enabled easy departure from the room and unlike most hotels with automatic doors , the mechanism was in good working order. The only issue was that the door was only automatic from inside the room , not on entry and overcoming the inertia  to push the door open was difficult. Getting out was a breeze Roomy entrance to bathroom and plenty of space for transfers both in bathroom and bedroom.
Beautifully, ornately decorated 17th century church with statues, which is well worth visiting.
Lots of seating around the centres as well as several coffee shops to stop in for a break. Ramps/lifts/escalators are available for every set of steps. Not every store had braille for signs etc.
The botanic's in Edinburgh is a joy to visit, inside it is modern and accessible, outside it is beautiful and even in a wheelchair I can appreciate a visit all that is on show.
Just over 3 miles from Droitwich town, with an easy to find route, a huge car park is available, with many disabled bays for you.

The cinema is situated in a entertainment complex so has a big car park with multiple disabled parking spots but there is 18 disabled parking spaces in front of the cinema to make accessibility easier.  The foot paths are also flat and wide to allow easy wheelchair use.

Accessible toilet which was easy to find. Had fold-down rail to left of toilet (when on toilet) and fixed rail on wall on right. Flush for the toilet seemed fairly high up if trying to reach it from sitting in a wheelchair.   Toilet clean and functional, but whole area just made of concrete blocks so wasn't the most attractive. A mirror would also be good to have.

When I visited I got dropped off so didn’t properly park in the car park but, from what I could see there weren’t any lines on the ground to mark out the parking spaces. I think people just parked in a uniformed fashion therefore, there aren’t any accessible parking spaces. The car park is surfaced in gravel stones and I can imagine it might be difficult for wheelchair users to drive on however, there is a wheelchair drop off area at the front of Cairn O’Mohr on the concrete pathway to make things easier.  I’m not from this area so, I can’t comment on any of the public transport.

Parking in the car park alongside the railway line and opposite the bus station. This is a short distance from the Railway carpark. Access to the fully tarmac path is across the gated railway line and is easy enough. There are at the time of writing two disabled spaces.

Although the front is level access, you need to go in the rear entrance because there are stairs to get everywhere from the front and the lift and accessible toilet are in the back. The staff have a temporary ramp that they put out when you ring the doorbell. The lift is tiny and a manual wheelchair could just about fit in but on my power wheelchair I need to take the footplates of in order to fit in.

Mostly helpful and if you've pre booked assistance to board or alight a train the help is provided. If you haven't booked there's a member of staff around before each train departs and staff in the train who can help when alighting. Generally lots of staff around if you have any questions.
There are 2 accessible toilets one on the ground floor and one upstairs beside the gymnasium. Both toilets are small but have handrails

Easiest boarding and travelling ever! When you get a ferry to Cumbrae (from Largs) you automatically gte sold a return ticket. This makes it easier for the return trip home! Calling Cumbrae Ferry Terminal a 'terminal' is probably a bit misleading - it's a parking area with a sign and you wait for the ferry to come in, cars and passengers to disembark, and then you roll on - simple!

Corfu has one airport. When I visited in April it was just before the start of the Greek holiday season. The airport was still being renovated and I was told a German company had taken it over. I had a bad experience but hopefully this was an out of season travel blip. However I was not impressed with the special assistance service.
Plenty of parking at the venue

Can't comment on the parking. Nearby Place Gambetta is extensively served by wheelchair accessible buses.  The cemetery is best entered by wheelchair at the gate at the end of Avenue du Père Lachaise, a short wheel or walk from Place Gambetta.
We used a taxi from Abu Dhabi. Taxis good value and easily available. On the whole drivers helpful.
5 if you have a car as you can park right outside. There is a bus stop nearby and we saw the bus zipping around the island but not sure if it's accessible or how often it runs.
There are only disabled loos beyond the ticket barriers.

The stewards were polite and helpful, indicating where we had to go immediately and in the stadium they held back people over-enthusiastically celebrating, which you cannot always guarantee. All in all people were helpful.
A fantastic parkland with a zoo, play area, golf course and a huge area of open area and is surprisingly accessible.
Very pleasant very helpful, very informative of the area

There were two large toilet cubicles accessible from the restaurant. One was slightly larger than the other with an outward opening door. There were no grab rails and it would have been a very tight squeeze for a carer.
Incredibly helpful. From showing us where to park to driving us to the top - I can't fault them - brilliant!

The premises entrance was sloped and so getting the wheelchair up and into the building was relatively easy. The door is a push from the outside which could cause issues if a wheelchair user is alone, although the staff are quick to come and help. The counter to order from was a little too high for wheelchair users and so can make them feel spoken down to. Level access around the ground floor of the building with plenty of spaces to sit suitable for a wheelchair user and the people who accompany them. Could easily access the condiments bar in the wheelchair with minimal effort required.

Access to Costa Coffee is via the main door of the Next store there are stairs to the left as you enter. The lift is on the right hand side of the Next store. The lift is the type that you need to hold the button down to go up or down. The door opens and closes automatically when you exit the lift you are in the Costa Coffee next to the counter to be served.
The sailing school provide free parking at the harbour although there is no specified disabled space

99% accessible, the only place some people couldn't go was the Mary Queen of Scots bed chamber, but there was a virtual tour instead.  The Queen's Gallery was super easy, the Palace a little more complicated, but generally ok.

The hotel entrance had level access with wide automatic doors leading to reception where you will find very friendly and helpful staff. As you go in through the entrance, to the left is a good sized accessible public  toilet. Once at reception there are also self check-in machines. There are two good sized lifts that take you to all levels.  My accessible room (room 331) was on the third floor and seemed to be furthest away from the lifts and we had to negotiate approx three doors in the corridors before getting to the room. The room itself was very spacious with plenty room for getting around. The bathroom did not have a wetroom roll-in shower but had a low level bath with a shower over it. I'm unsure if this is standard in this hotel or if other rooms were fitted with wetrooms. The Lounge bar/dining area is on floor -1 in the lift and there was plenty space and staff were very helpful at moving chairs etc. At breakfast, it is a buffet style but the staff would be more than happy to assist getting it for you if required. It can get a busy at certain times but nothing to get concerned about.

Large space for parking several vehicles. Bus stop 10 minutes walk , no pavement and along a narrow country lane. Not much passing traffic. Bus service was reliable and a good service to surrounding areas.

We didn't see a disabled toilet in the hotel where the other toilets were but I wouldn't be able to use it without a hoist anyway. The toilet in the bedroom couldn't be accessed with a hoist alone because the space wasn't in the room to use it. Going into the shower/toilet room was OK but to get out was an issue unless you backed out as the hard front casters got cough in the laminate floor trim between the tiles in the shower/toilet room and the laminate floor in the bedroom.
Yes helpful but not excessively so, members of the public were useful.

Not brilliant, apart from the large taxi rank by "The Playhouse" next door.  Public transport is good with regular buses to nearby Princes Street & Leith Walk. (Personally, I came by taxi and my friend - who lives in Bonnyrigg, by bus.)`

The building has several accessible toilets. All equipped and finished to a high standard.   However, for us the crowning glory was the discovery of a Changing Places Toilet. Handily tucked away at the side of the tour reception hall.  Beautifully equipped and decorated to exactly the same high specification as all the other toilets. No medical looking white grab rails in this set up!
There is a ramped access at the front of the restaurant and a big conservatory which is a good place to sit if you want more space.

No designated disabled spaces that I could see. I did park further away from the play park area though as I took my dog on a long walk however, there is a car park right next to the play area and there might be disabled spaces there. There is a bus stop just outside the park, but I would recommend going by car as you would have to walk up a road to get to the park and it's quite a distance.
lots of disabled parking outside doors
The entrance to the hotel is situated in its own car park with space outside the front door to drop off and pick up
The entrance to the building and café is wheelchair accessible. However, inside the café, there is a step to access the food, beverages and the billing counter.

Staff and volunteers are exceptional, extremely helpful. Not able to manage on your own? Shopmobility offer a Companion shopping service where we can push your wheelchair or Sighted Guide for the visually impaired too. Get in touch for more details.

Currently the shop isn’t open so you just roll to the door and they pass you your ice cream. Once the shop opens next week there is a tiny step into the milk bar which is easily conquered by wheelchairs. In the shop it can be a little hard to manoeuvre if it’s busy but Mary and the staff are great at keeping an eye out for anyone who might need help and giving it.
Really good level access through-out. Only the aquarium couldn't be reached in a wheelchair but this was made clear from the outset. Great day for everyone.

Wide doors, not automatic but a member of staff came as soon as I tried to open the door. Room to get round in a chair but easily accessible tables at the door and by the bar. The chairs have arms which is important for me to help me transfer. Also chairs with no arms if you prefer to slide to transfer.

We visited here as a family of 3, we booked seats in the Everton family enclosure as away supporters. Although we didn't book disabled access seats I arrived in my wheelchair and asked to store the chair. They agreed and were very helpful. Also showed us to our seats. Great seats for anyone struggling to walk distances.
You would need to get a train and walk or use the parking facilities that are a two minute walk away
Attentive efficient friendly

This hotel advertises itself to be wheelchair friendly. This was not the case. The lift to the bedrooms was miniscule. I really struggled to even get in. The room was so small that I could not get past the bottom of the bed. It was impossible for us to stay. The staff were lovely. We were given a complimentary drink ( and a bowl of soup) because we had been travelling all day. We were also given a full refund without any quibble. It would pay to take measurements before booking.
Plenty of space in wet room for wheelchair or showerchair and carer
Free disabled parking 25 metres from museum. Disabled drop off. Level access from car park.
Very smart accessible loo! If the bar is busy it is a little trickier to get to with how some of the seating is arranged but this is just a small thing.
Quick visit to ASDA in Newmains during the lockdown. Social distancing measures were in place and it felt quite safe.

Accessible toilet down corridor- slightly impeded by a table that obstructed the corridor. If using wheelchair this would need to be moved. Toilet accessed via double door. Appropriate grab rails available in the toilet with call bell also. Toilet clean and tidy with appropriate room to manoeuvre wheelchair around or for a carer to assist.

Some on street tables under heated awning, with table service; very steep ramp into the main part of the restaurant - access up and down the ramp definitely needing heavy shove and assistance from helpers

The store was level access from the St. Enoch Centre with an open plan frontage. Once in the store there was plenty of space for us as powerchair users to easily browse around without fear of demolishing the displays (not unheard of in our case)!  Everything was easy to see and well arranged.
There is a multi-storey car park directly opposite the school, and just beside that is an underground station (shields road).  Buses also are in this area, but we didn't use them.
There are lots of toilets through out the centre which are accessible.

On the sea front by the old West Pier, the i360 offers a ride in a pod to a height of 450 feet. Disabled friendly with no steps & a lift from street level to the promenade (a useful facility even if not riding the i360).  Very spacious taking two wheelchairs on each ride, with plenty of room to move around, particularly when quiet. The visitors area has a disabled toilet & the adjacent restaurant is equally disabled friendly. Carers travel free, but can only be booked by phone or on the day.

Usually excellent.  We once had a problem with one staff member's attitude but complained to the management who were really good about it (that member of staff turned out to be only temporary anyway).
Staff friendly and helpful. Helped with platform lift between shop and ground floors. Normal lift to other floors.
We parked in The Swan Hotel where we were staying so there was no problem.
The  disabled access toilet is conveniently situated by the stalls.
All staff very friendly and approachable ., will help with anything you need
a Gravel drive from the road to the 'Lodge', with hard and level paving to designated disabled parking bay
It was accessible with a lift access.   But the small windows upstairs are all a bit high.
I have always arrived via public transport. Taxi's can stop right outside the building and there is a bus stop just a minute away from the building.
Toilet facilities are clearly delineated, with the disabled toilets having good accessibility and room inside if you need someone with you.

This is a good size café located with in one of the stands and is near to the ticket collection point and is very easy to find the café offers a wide range of food and drinks and is open even on non match days which is when we visited.  The café has a range of styles of seating including booths but mostly made up of table with dinning room chairs to allow a wheelchair to access the space. The lighting with in the  café is good and there are large screens showing sky sports news the sound is however off.  While it was not that busy during our visit they do recommend you book a table if there is a match on which is understandable due to numbers
